Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

cards.name: Pride of the Road
cards.originalText:
Vigilance
Start your engines (If you have no speed, it starts at 1. It increases once on each of your turns when an opponent loses life. Max speed is 4.)
Max speed ‚Äî At the beginning of combat on your turn, target creature or Vehicle you control gains double strike until end of turn.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

cards.name: Swiftwing Assailant
cards.originalText:
Flying
Start your engines (If you have no speed, it starts at 1. It increases once on each of your turns when an opponent loses life. Max speed is 4.)
Max speed ‚Äî This creature gets +0/+1 and has vigilance.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

cards.name: Aether Syphon
cards.originalText:
Start your engines (If you have no speed, it starts at 1. It increases once on each of your turns when an opponent loses life. Max speed is 4.)
{2}, {T}: Draw a card.
Max speed ‚Äî Whenever you draw a card, each opponent mills two cards. (Each opponent puts the top two cards of their library into their graveyard.)

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

cards.name: Glitch Ghost Surveyor
cards.originalText:
Flying
Start your engines (If you have no speed, it starts at 1. It increases once on each of your turns when an opponent loses life. Max speed is 4.)
Max speed ‚Äî {3}, Exile this card from your graveyard: Draw a card.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

cards.name: Vnwxt, Verbose Host
cards.originalText:
Start your engines (If you have no speed, it starts at 1. It increases once on each of your turns when an opponent loses life. Max speed is 4.)
You have no maximum hand size.
Max speed ‚Äî If you would draw a card, draw two cards instead.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If a spell or ability causes you to draw multiple cards, this creature‚Äôs last ability doubles each card draw. For example, if you cast Harmonize (‚ÄúDraw three cards‚Äù), you‚Äôll draw six cards.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.
If two or more replacement effects would apply to a card-drawing event, the player who‚Äôs drawing the card chooses what order to apply them.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

The effects of multiple such effects are cumulative. For example, if you have max speed and control both Vnwxt and Thought Reflection (an enchantment with the same ability), you‚Äôll draw four times the original number of cards.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

cards.name: Ancient Vendetta
cards.originalText: Choose a card name. Search target opponent's graveyard, hand, and library for up to four cards with that name and exile them. Then that player shuffles.

rulings.text: The ability has no effect on permanents with the chosen name that are on the battlefield.
Unlike similar cards, Ancient Vendetta allows you to choose the name of a basic land. Note that you may only search for up to four cards with the chosen name, even if you find more of them.
You don‚Äôt have to choose the name of a card that you‚Äôve already seen this game; you may guess at a card you think your opponent might have in their hand or library, if you‚Äôd like.
You don‚Äôt have to exile each card you find with that name. If you want to leave one in their graveyard, for example, you may.

You target a player as this spell is put on the stack, but you don‚Äôt name a card until it resolves. Notably, this means that players don‚Äôt get to respond to the spell knowing what card you will name.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

cards.name: Risen Necroregent
cards.originalText:
Start your engines (If you have no speed, it starts at 1. It increases once on each of your turns when an opponent loses life. Max speed is 4.)
Max speed ‚Äî At the beginning of your end step, create a 2/2 black Zombie creature token.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

cards.name: Streaking Oilgorger
cards.originalText:
Flying, haste
Start your engines (If you have no speed, it starts at 1. It increases once on each of your turns when an opponent loses life. Max speed is 4.)
Max speed ‚Äî This creature has lifelink.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

cards.name: Adrenaline Jockey
cards.originalText:
Whenever a player casts a spell, if it's not their turn, this creature deals 4 damage to them.
Whenever you activate an exhaust ability, put a +1/+1 counter on this creature.

rulings.text: Exhaust abilities can be activated any time you could normally activate an ability.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

cards.name: Goblin Surveyor
cards.originalText:
Trample
Start your engines (If you have no speed, it starts at 1. It increases once on each of your turns when an opponent loses life. Max speed is 4.)
Max speed ‚Äî {3}, Exile this card from your graveyard: Draw a card.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

rulings.text: Some cards with cycling have an ability that triggers when you cycle them, and some cards have an ability that triggers whenever you cycle any card or discard any card. These triggered abilities resolve before you draw from the cycling ability.
Triggered abilities from cycling a card and the cycling ability itself aren‚Äôt spells. Effects that interact with spells (such as that of Cancel) won‚Äôt affect them.

You can cycle a card even if it has a triggered ability from cycling that won‚Äôt have a legal target. This is because the cycling ability and the triggered ability are separate. This also means that if either ability is countered (with Disallow, for example), the other ability will still resolve.

cards.name: Outpace Oblivion
cards.originalText:
Start your engines (If you have no speed, it starts at 1. It increases once on each of your turns when an opponent loses life. Max speed is 4.)
When this enchantment enters, it deals 5 damage to up to one target creature or planeswalker.
{2}, Sacrifice this enchantment: It deals 2 damage to each player who doesn't have max speed.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

cards.name: Agonasaur Rex
cards.originalText:
Trample
Cycling {2}{G} ({2}{G}, Discard this card: Draw a card.)
When you cycle this card, put two +1/+1 counters on up to one target creature or Vehicle. It gains trample and indestructible until end of turn.

rulings.text: Some cards with cycling have an ability that triggers when you cycle them, and some cards have an ability that triggers whenever you cycle any card or discard any card. These triggered abilities resolve before you draw from the cycling ability.
Triggered abilities from cycling a card and the cycling ability itself aren‚Äôt spells. Effects that interact with spells (such as that of Cancel) won‚Äôt affect them.

You can cycle a card even if it has a triggered ability from cycling that won‚Äôt have a legal target. This is because the cycling ability and the triggered ability are separate. This also means that if either ability is countered (with Disallow, for example), the other ability will still resolve.

cards.originalText:
Start your engines (If you have no speed, it starts at 1. It increases once on each of your turns when an opponent loses life. Max speed is 4.)
Max speed ‚Äî {3}, Exile this card from your graveyard: Draw a card.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

cards.name: Point the Way
cards.originalText:
Start your engines (If you have no speed, it starts at 1. It increases once on each of your turns when an opponent loses life. Max speed is 4.)
{3}{G}, Sacrifice this enchantment: Search your library for up to X basic land cards, where X is your speed. Put those cards onto the battlefield tapped, then shuffle.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

Some cards with cycling have an ability that triggers when you cycle them, and some cards have an ability that triggers whenever you cycle any card or discard any card. These triggered abilities resolve before you draw from the cycling ability.
Triggered abilities from cycling a card and the cycling ability itself aren‚Äôt spells. Effects that interact with spells (such as that of Cancel) won‚Äôt affect them.

You can cycle a card even if it has a triggered ability from cycling that won‚Äôt have a legal target. This is because the cycling ability and the triggered ability are separate. This also means that if either ability is countered (with Disallow, for example), the other ability will still resolve.

cards.originalText:
Menace, deathtouch
When this creature enters, put target creature card with mana value 4 or less from a graveyard onto the battlefield under your control with a finality counter on it. That creature gains menace, deathtouch, and haste. At the beginning of your next end step, exile that creature.

rulings.text: Finality counters aren‚Äôt keyword counters, and a finality counter doesn‚Äôt give any abilities to the permanent it‚Äôs on. If that permanent loses its abilities and then would go to a graveyard, it will still be exiled instead.

Finality counters don‚Äôt stop permanents from going to zones other than the graveyard from the battlefield. For example, if a permanent with a finality counter on it would be put into its owner‚Äôs hand from the battlefield, it does so normally.
Finality counters work on any permanent, not only creatures. If a permanent with a finality counter on it would be put into a graveyard from the battlefield, exile it instead.
Multiple finality counters on a single permanent are redundant.

cards.name: Embalmed Ascendant
cards.originalText:
Start your engines (If you have no speed, it starts at 1. It increases once on each of your turns when an opponent loses life. Max speed is 4.)
When this creature enters, create a 2/2 black Zombie creature token.
Max speed ‚Äî Whenever a creature you control dies, each opponent loses 1 life and you gain 1 life.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

cards.name: Far Fortune, End Boss
cards.originalText:
Start your engines (If you have no speed, it starts at 1. It increases once on each of your turns when an opponent loses life. Max speed is 4.)
Whenever you attack, Far Fortune deals 1 damage to each opponent.
Max speed ‚Äî If a source you control would deal damage to an opponent or a permanent an opponent controls, it deals that much damage plus 1 instead.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

If another effect modifies how much damage your sources would deal, including preventing some of it, the player being dealt damage or the controller of the permanent being dealt damage chooses an order in which to apply those effects. If all of the damage is prevented, Far Fortune‚Äôs last ability no longer applies.

If damage dealt by a source you control is being divided or assigned among multiple permanents an opponent controls or among an opponent and one or more permanents they control, divide the original amount before adding 1. For example, if you attack with a 5/5 creature with trample and your opponent blocks with a 2/2 creature, you can assign 2 damage to the blocker and 3 damage to the defending player. These amounts are then modified to 3 and 4, respectively.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

The additional 1 damage from Far Fortune‚Äôs last ability is dealt by the same source as the original source of damage. The damage isn‚Äôt dealt by Far Fortune unless Far Fortune is the original source of damage.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

cards.name: Mendicant Core, Guidelight
cards.originalText:
Mendicant Core's power is equal to the number of artifacts you control.
Start your engines (If you have no speed, it starts at 1. It increases once on each of your turns when an opponent loses life. Max speed is 4.)
Max speed ‚Äî Whenever you cast an artifact spell, you may pay {1}. If you do, copy it. (The copy becomes a token.)

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.

A resolving copy of a permanent spell becomes a token, so the token isn‚Äôt ‚Äúcreated.‚Äù Effects that care about a token being created won‚Äôt interact with a token that enters the battlefield from Mendicant Core‚Äôs last ability.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

The copy remembers any decisions that were made for the original spell as it was cast, including values chosen for X in its mana cost and whether any alternative or additional costs were chosen. For example, if the original artifact spell had kicker and its kicker cost was paid, the copy will also be kicked.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

cards.name: Starting Column
cards.originalText:
Start your engines (If you have no speed, it starts at 1. It increases once on each of your turns when an opponent loses life. Max speed is 4.)
{T}: Add one mana of any color.
Max speed ‚Äî {T}, Sacrifice this artifact: Draw two cards, then discard a card.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

cards.name: Muraganda Raceway
cards.originalText:
Start your engines (If you have no speed, it starts at 1. It increases once on each of your turns when an opponent loses life. Max speed is 4.)
{T}: Add {C}.
Max speed ‚Äî {T}: Add {C}{C}.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

If an ability triggers whenever you activate an exhaust ability, that ability resolves before the exhaust ability resolves.

rulings.text: Bloodghast's landfall ability triggers only if it's already in your graveyard at the time a land enters under your control.
A landfall ability doesn't trigger if a permanent already on the battlefield becomes a land.

A landfall ability triggers whenever a land you control enters for any reason. It triggers whenever you play a land, as well as whenever a spell or ability puts a land onto the battlefield under your control.

Whenever a land you control enters, each landfall ability of the permanents you control will trigger. You can put them ¬†¬†on the stack in any order. The last ability you put on the stack will be the first one to resolve (As a result, you can have those abilities resolve in the order of your choosing.).

rulings.text: Some cards with cycling have an ability that triggers when you cycle them, and some cards have an ability that triggers whenever you cycle any card or discard any card. These triggered abilities resolve before you draw from the cycling ability.
Triggered abilities from cycling a card and the cycling ability itself aren‚Äôt spells. Effects that interact with spells (such as that of Cancel) won‚Äôt affect them.

You can cycle a card even if it has a triggered ability from cycling that won‚Äôt have a legal target. This is because the cycling ability and the triggered ability are separate. This also means that if either ability is countered (with Disallow, for example), the other ability will still resolve.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
After the activated ability resolves, the creature can‚Äôt be blocked this turn even if its power later increases to 3 or greater.

Hazoret‚Äôs activated ability must be used prior to declaring blockers to be effective. Activating it targeting a creature that has already been blocked will not cause that creature to become unblocked.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

cards.name: Vnwxt, Verbose Host
cards.originalText:
Start your engines
You have no maximum hand size.
Max speed ‚Äî If you would draw a card, draw two cards instead.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If a spell or ability causes you to draw multiple cards, this creature‚Äôs last ability doubles each card draw. For example, if you cast Harmonize (‚ÄúDraw three cards‚Äù), you‚Äôll draw six cards.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.
If two or more replacement effects would apply to a card-drawing event, the player who‚Äôs drawing the card chooses what order to apply them.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

The effects of multiple such effects are cumulative. For example, if you have max speed and control both Vnwxt and Thought Reflection (an enchantment with the same ability), you‚Äôll draw four times the original number of cards.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

cards.name: Far Fortune, End Boss
cards.originalText:
Start your engines
Whenever you attack, Far Fortune deals 1 damage to each opponent.
Max speed ‚Äî If a source you control would deal damage to an opponent or a permanent an opponent controls, it deals that much damage plus 1 instead.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

If another effect modifies how much damage your sources would deal, including preventing some of it, the player being dealt damage or the controller of the permanent being dealt damage chooses an order in which to apply those effects. If all of the damage is prevented, Far Fortune‚Äôs last ability no longer applies.

If damage dealt by a source you control is being divided or assigned among multiple permanents an opponent controls or among an opponent and one or more permanents they control, divide the original amount before adding 1. For example, if you attack with a 5/5 creature with trample and your opponent blocks with a 2/2 creature, you can assign 2 damage to the blocker and 3 damage to the defending player. These amounts are then modified to 3 and 4, respectively.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

The additional 1 damage from Far Fortune‚Äôs last ability is dealt by the same source as the original source of damage. The damage isn‚Äôt dealt by Far Fortune unless Far Fortune is the original source of damage.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

cards.name: Cursecloth Wrappings
cards.originalText:
Zombies you control get +1/+1.
{T}: Target creature card in your graveyard gains embalm until end of turn. The embalm cost is equal to its mana cost.

rulings.text: Except for the listed exceptions, the token copies exactly what was printed on the original card and nothing else. It doesn‚Äôt copy any information about the object the card was before it was put into your graveyard.

If the card copied by the token had any ‚Äúwhen [this permanent] enters‚Äù abilities, then the token also has those abilities and they‚Äôll trigger when it enters. Similarly, any ‚Äúas [this permanent] enters‚Äù or ‚Äú[this permanent] enters with‚Äù abilities that the token has copied will also work.
Once you‚Äôve activated an embalm ability, the card is immediately exiled. Opponents can‚Äôt try to stop the ability by exiling the card.

The token is a Zombie in addition to its other types and is white instead of its other colors. It has no mana cost, and thus its mana value is 0. These are copiable values of the token that other effects may copy.

cards.text:
Zombies you control get +1/+1.
{T}: Target creature card in your graveyard gains embalm until end of turn. The embalm cost is equal to its mana cost. (Exile that card and pay its embalm cost: Create a token that's a copy of it, except it's a white Zombie in addition to its other types and has no mana cost. Embalm only as a sorcery.)

cards.name: Loot, the Pathfinder
cards.originalText:
Double strike, vigilance, haste
Exhaust ‚Äî {G}, {T}: Add three mana of any one color.
Exhaust ‚Äî {U}, {T}: Draw three cards.
Exhaust ‚Äî {R}, {T}: Loot deals 3 damage to any target.

rulings.text: Exhaust abilities can be activated any time you could normally activate an ability.
If an ability triggers whenever you activate an exhaust ability, that ability resolves before the exhaust ability resolves.

If an exhaust ability of a permanent is activated, and then that permanent leaves the battlefield and returns to the battlefield, it becomes a new object so its exhaust ability can be activated again.

‚ÄúSaddle N‚Äù means ‚ÄúTap any number of other untapped creatures you control with total power N or greater: This permanent becomes saddled until end of turn. Activate only as a sorcery.‚Äù
‚ÄúSaddled‚Äù isn‚Äôt an ability that a creature has. It‚Äôs just something true about that creature. It won‚Äôt stop being saddled until the turn ends or it leaves the battlefield.

When this artifact enters, exile target nonland permanent an opponent controls until this artifact leaves the battlefield.
Max speed ‚Äî {T}: Put a +1/+1 counter on target creature or Vehicle you control. Activate only as a sorcery.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

cards.name: Vnwxt, Verbose Host
cards.originalText:
Start your engines
You have no maximum hand size.
Max speed ‚Äî If you would draw a card, draw two cards instead.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If a spell or ability causes you to draw multiple cards, this creature‚Äôs last ability doubles each card draw. For example, if you cast Harmonize (‚ÄúDraw three cards‚Äù), you‚Äôll draw six cards.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.
If two or more replacement effects would apply to a card-drawing event, the player who‚Äôs drawing the card chooses what order to apply them.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

The effects of multiple such effects are cumulative. For example, if you have max speed and control both Vnwxt and Thought Reflection (an enchantment with the same ability), you‚Äôll draw four times the original number of cards.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

A landfall ability doesn't trigger if a permanent already on the battlefield becomes a land.

A landfall ability triggers whenever a land you control enters for any reason. It triggers whenever you play a land, as well as whenever a spell or ability puts a land onto the battlefield under your control.

Whenever a land you control enters, each landfall ability of the permanents you control will trigger. You can put them ¬†¬†on the stack in any order. The last ability you put on the stack will be the first one to resolve (As a result, you can have those abilities resolve in the order of your choosing.).

rulings.text: Except for the listed exceptions, the token copies exactly what was printed on the original card and nothing else. It doesn‚Äôt copy any information about the object the card was before it was put into your graveyard.

If the card copied by the token had any ‚Äúwhen [this permanent] enters‚Äù abilities, then the token also has those abilities and they‚Äôll trigger when it enters. Similarly, any ‚Äúas [this permanent] enters‚Äù or ‚Äú[this permanent] enters with‚Äù abilities that the token has copied will also work.
Once you‚Äôve activated an embalm ability, the card is immediately exiled. Opponents can‚Äôt try to stop the ability by exiling the card.

The token is a Zombie in addition to its other types and is white instead of its other colors. It has no mana cost, and thus its mana value is 0. These are copiable values of the token that other effects may copy.

rulings.text: Exhaust abilities can be activated any time you could normally activate an ability.
If an ability triggers whenever you activate an exhaust ability, that ability resolves before the exhaust ability resolves.

If an exhaust ability of a permanent is activated, and then that permanent leaves the battlefield and returns to the battlefield, it becomes a new object so its exhaust ability can be activated again.
You may spend the four mana added by the first ability on the same ability or on multiple abilities.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

rulings.text: Some cards with cycling have an ability that triggers when you cycle them, and some cards have an ability that triggers whenever you cycle any card or discard any card. These triggered abilities resolve before you draw from the cycling ability.
Triggered abilities from cycling a card and the cycling ability itself aren‚Äôt spells. Effects that interact with spells (such as that of Cancel) won‚Äôt affect them.

You can cycle a card even if it has a triggered ability from cycling that won‚Äôt have a legal target. This is because the cycling ability and the triggered ability are separate. This also means that if either ability is countered (with Disallow, for example), the other ability will still resolve.

rulings.text: An ability that triggers when a creature ‚Äúattacks while saddled‚Äù will trigger only if that creature was saddled when it was declared as an attacker.
Creatures with saddle can attack or block as normal even if they aren‚Äôt saddled.
If a permanent becomes a copy of a saddled Mount, the copy won‚Äôt be saddled.
You may activate a permanent‚Äôs saddle ability even if that permanent is already saddled.
‚ÄúSaddle N‚Äù means ‚ÄúTap any number of other untapped creatures you control with total power N or greater: This permanent becomes saddled until end of turn. Activate only as a sorcery.‚Äù
‚ÄúSaddled‚Äù isn‚Äôt an ability that a creature has. It‚Äôs just something true about that creature. It won‚Äôt stop being saddled until the turn ends or it leaves the battlefield.

rulings.text: If there‚Äôs an {X} in a permanent‚Äôs mana cost, X is 0 when determining its mana value.

Some cards with cycling have an ability that triggers when you cycle them, and some cards have an ability that triggers whenever you cycle any card or discard any card. These triggered abilities resolve before you draw from the cycling ability.
Triggered abilities from cycling a card and the cycling ability itself aren‚Äôt spells. Effects that interact with spells (such as that of Cancel) won‚Äôt affect them.

You can cycle a card even if it has a triggered ability from cycling that won‚Äôt have a legal target. This is because the cycling ability and the triggered ability are separate. This also means that if either ability is countered (with Disallow, for example), the other ability will still resolve.

cards.originalText:
Menace, deathtouch
When this creature enters, put target creature card with mana value 4 or less from a graveyard onto the battlefield under your control with a finality counter on it. That creature gains menace, deathtouch, and haste. At the beginning of your next end step, exile that creature.

rulings.text: Finality counters aren‚Äôt keyword counters, and a finality counter doesn‚Äôt give any abilities to the permanent it‚Äôs on. If that permanent loses its abilities and then would go to a graveyard, it will still be exiled instead.

Finality counters don‚Äôt stop permanents from going to zones other than the graveyard from the battlefield. For example, if a permanent with a finality counter on it would be put into its owner‚Äôs hand from the battlefield, it does so normally.
Finality counters work on any permanent, not only creatures. If a permanent with a finality counter on it would be put into a graveyard from the battlefield, exile it instead.
Multiple finality counters on a single permanent are redundant.

cards.name: Far Fortune, End Boss
cards.originalText:
Start your engines
Whenever you attack, Far Fortune deals 1 damage to each opponent.
Max speed ‚Äî If a source you control would deal damage to an opponent or a permanent an opponent controls, it deals that much damage plus 1 instead.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

If another effect modifies how much damage your sources would deal, including preventing some of it, the player being dealt damage or the controller of the permanent being dealt damage chooses an order in which to apply those effects. If all of the damage is prevented, Far Fortune‚Äôs last ability no longer applies.

If damage dealt by a source you control is being divided or assigned among multiple permanents an opponent controls or among an opponent and one or more permanents they control, divide the original amount before adding 1. For example, if you attack with a 5/5 creature with trample and your opponent blocks with a 2/2 creature, you can assign 2 damage to the blocker and 3 damage to the defending player. These amounts are then modified to 3 and 4, respectively.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

The additional 1 damage from Far Fortune‚Äôs last ability is dealt by the same source as the original source of damage. The damage isn‚Äôt dealt by Far Fortune unless Far Fortune is the original source of damage.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

cards.name: Mendicant Core, Guidelight
cards.originalText:
Mendicant Core's power is equal to the number of artifacts you control.
Start your engines
Max speed ‚Äî Whenever you cast an artifact spell, you may pay {1}. If you do, copy it.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.

A resolving copy of a permanent spell becomes a token, so the token isn‚Äôt ‚Äúcreated.‚Äù Effects that care about a token being created won‚Äôt interact with a token that enters the battlefield from Mendicant Core‚Äôs last ability.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

The copy remembers any decisions that were made for the original spell as it was cast, including values chosen for X in its mana cost and whether any alternative or additional costs were chosen. For example, if the original artifact spell had kicker and its kicker cost was paid, the copy will also be kicked.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

cards.originalText:
Start your engines
{T}: Add {C}.
Max speed ‚Äî {T}: Add {C}{C}.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

cards.name: Hazoret, Godseeker
cards.originalText:
Indestructible, haste
Start your engines
{1}, {T}: Target creature with power 2 or less can't be blocked this turn.
Hazoret can't attack or block unless you have max speed.

rulings.text: A player ‚Äúhas max speed‚Äù if their speed is 4.
After the activated ability resolves, the creature can‚Äôt be blocked this turn even if its power later increases to 3 or greater.
Each player tracks their speed (or lack thereof) separately. Increasing your speed has no effect on whether another player has speed.

Hazoret‚Äôs activated ability must be used prior to declaring blockers to be effective. Activating it targeting a creature that has already been blocked will not cause that creature to become unblocked.
If an effect needs to know what a player‚Äôs speed is and that player doesn‚Äôt have a speed, their speed is considered 0.

Start your engines! isn‚Äôt a triggered ability. Increasing your speed to 1 is something that happens as a state-based action as soon as you control a permanent with the ability. Notably, this includes gaining control of a permanent with the ability that another player controls.

Your speed doesn‚Äôt change until a spell or ability says so, such as the inherent triggered ability that cares about opponents losing life during your turn. Notably, losing control of permanents with start your engines! doesn‚Äôt affect your speed.

‚ÄúMax speed ‚Äî [ability]‚Äù means ‚ÄúAs long as you have max speed, this object has [ability].‚Äù If the granted ability functions in a zone other than the battlefield, the max speed ability does too.

rulings.text: Finality counters aren‚Äôt keyword counters, and a finality counter doesn‚Äôt give any abilities to the permanent it‚Äôs on. If that permanent loses its abilities and then would go to a graveyard, it will still be exiled instead.

Finality counters don‚Äôt stop permanents from going to zones other than the graveyard from the battlefield. For example, if a permanent with a finality counter on it would be put into its owner‚Äôs hand from the battlefield, it does so normally.
Finality counters work on any permanent, not only creatures. If a permanent with a finality counter on it would be put into a graveyard from the battlefield, exile it instead.
Multiple finality counters on a single permanent are redundant.
